factoid: O-hoy is a huntsman's call that combines deep bass with shrill tenor.
Daniel is the head huntsman and head kennelman.
Daniel is a gray, wrinkled old man.
Daniel has hair cut straight over his forehead.
Daniel wears Ukrainian fashion.
Daniel holds a long bent whip in his hand.
Daniel has a look of independence.
Daniel has a look of scorn.
Daniel doffed his Circassian cap to Nicholas.
Daniel looked at Nicholas scornfully.
Daniel's scorn was not offensive to Nicholas.
Nicholas knew that Daniel was his serf and huntsman.
Nicholas was conscious at the sight of the weather.
Nicholas was conscious at the sight of the hounds.
Nicholas was conscious at the sight of the huntsman.
Nicholas was being carried away by an irresistible passion for sport.
The passion for sport makes a man forget all his previous resolutions.
The passion for sport makes a man forget like a lover in the presence of a mistress.
The huntsman asked what orders Nicholas had.
The huntsman's voice was deep as a proto-deacon's.
The huntsman's voice was hoarse with hallooing.
The huntsman had two flashing black eyes.
The huntsman's eyes gazed from under his brows at Nicholas.
The huntsman's eyes seemed to ask 'Can you resist it?'.
Nicholas asked if it was a good day for a hunt and a gallop.
Nicholas scratched Mílka behind the ears.
Daniel did not answer but winked.
Daniel sent Uvárka at dawn to listen.
Uvárka said she moved them into the Otrádnoe enclosure.
Uvárka said they were howling there.
The she-wolf and her cubs moved to the Otrádnoe copse.
The Otrádnoe copse is a small place a mile and a half from the house.
Nicholas said we ought to go, don't you think so?
Nicholas said come to me with Uvárka.
Daniel replied as you please.
Nicholas said then put off feeding them.
Daniel replied yes, sir.
Five minutes later Daniel and Uvárka were standing in Nicholas' big study.
Daniel was not a big man.
Seeing Daniel in a room was like seeing a horse or a bear on the floor among furniture.
Daniel stood just inside the door.
Daniel tried to speak softly and not move.
Daniel feared breaking something in Nicholas' apartment.
Daniel hastened to say all that was necessary.
Daniel wanted to get from under the ceiling to the open sky.
Nicholas ordered the horses to be saddled.
Daniel wished to go hunting.
Natásha came in with rapid steps.
Natásha had not done up her hair.
Natásha had not finished dressing.
Natásha had her old nurse's big shawl wrapped round her.
Pétya ran in at the same time.
Natásha asked if Nicholas was going.
Natásha said she knew Nicholas would go.
Natásha said Sónya had said Nicholas wouldn't go.
Natásha said she knew that today was a sort of day when Nicholas couldn't help going.
Nicholas replied we are going reluctantly.
Nicholas did not want to take Natásha and Pétya.
Nicholas said we are going but only wolf hunting.
Nicholas said it would be dull for Natásha.
Natásha said it is her greatest pleasure.
Natásha said it's not fair; Nicholas is going by himself and has the horses saddled and said nothing to us.
Pétya shouted no barrier bars a Russian's path—we'll go.
Nicholas said but you can't.
Nicholas said Mamma said you mustn't.
Natásha said yes, I'll go.
Natásha said I shall certainly go.
Natásha said Daniel, tell them to saddle for us.
Natásha said Michael must come with my dogs.
Daniel found it irksome and improper to be in a room.
Daniel found it impossible to have anything to do with a young lady.
Daniel cast down his eyes.
Daniel hurried out.
Daniel was careful not to inflict accidental injury on the young lady.
The old count had always kept up an enormous hunting establishment.
The old count had handed it all over to his son's care.
The old count was in very good spirits on the fifteenth of September.
The old count prepared to go out with the others.
